text: I tried to do something that I logically thought would work.  It did not, so I wanted to know was it my fault or was it not a function of betfairlightweight. I accepted others opinion that it was not a function of betfairlightweight and was happy with that so "onwards and upwards" to other things.  It is not the only thing I have done with betfairlightweight which work so I am happy to forget about greyhounds for the moment and work on other things.

text: <@UUE6E1LA1> in what programming languge are you programming these day? Historically I went from 8080 assembler (well yes that is not programming language), basic, c, visual basic, pascal, c++, lisp, php, C#, Objective-C, F#, python, and many more but I count only those programming languages I made some app used by others. Yes I am not expert in python, and frankly to say it will not happen language of my choice.

Yes I am not expert in python, and frankly to say it will not happen language of my choice.

text: <@U013MLED3V1> I use C++ and node.js for anything bot related now. I really like node for simple tasks like price pulling or profit checking as you can get something  robust with just a few lines of code. I like that it is async too.

text: <@U013MLED3V1> I'm surprised Delphi isn't in your list considering it's the RAD version of pascal...

elements.text: I'm surprised Delphi isn't in your list considering it's the RAD version of pascal...

text: <@U017A7TRF6E> I had to endure embarcedero "RAD" studio for C++ dev for part of my work in my last job. Maybe the delphi aspect of that tool is a lot better and more reliable than the C++ side of it but in my experience, the application development was far from "rapid" because the IDE and tools were flakey. Maybe it is a lot better now.

text: I'm hoping not... call me opinionated, but I think Delphi shouldn't be used these days - I used to use it back in 2000 (in Uni) - and even then it was losing popularity. Nothing majorly wrong with it, but to me it's just "aged" badly - the one thing I did like about it was that you could write inline assembly direct into the code - made for some interesting features..

text: IDE's are a lot of better these days, but I think what is more important is how you can express yourself in code. For instance, can you code 2-3 hours, then press run and all works as expressed in code. That is really not what are my experiences when programming in some programming languages.

text: I know exactly what you mean. Give me 2 hours with C or C++ and I'd barely be able to get hello world on the go and I've actually used them both in the past, ..but nodejs for example I took to very quickly when I first tried it last year and had a full web app up and running in a day...  Some languages you just click with and simply "get".. others it's like chewing an old boot with no teeth...

text: <@U013MLED3V1> C and C++ are not type safe but it does not mean they are not useful. Yes you must declare variables to be of specified type but these things can be circumvented very easily  - intentionally and unintentionally. Just my opinion. Do any TRULY type safe languages exist?

elements.text: C and C++ are not type safe but it does not mean they are not useful. Yes you must declare variables to be of specified type but these things can be circumvented very easily  - intentionally and unintentionally. Just my opinion. Do any TRULY type safe languages exist?

text: C++ is type safe, actually that was its main advertise feature back in 70's when C was extended. Well of course I do not talk about pointers and conversion to any type/class/object.

elements.text: C++ is type safe, actually that was its main advertise feature back in 70's when C was extended. Well of course I do not talk about pointers and conversion to any type/class/object.

text: I've used it for close to 20 years now and I would say that you can advertise it as type safe but any language with an operation labelled reinterpret_cast (never mind having to support the C style cast) just can't be. Maybe in the hands of the perfect programmer who knows every line of the ever changing language standards AND never makes an error you could consider it type safe, but in practical terms it is not. For sure it is an improvement on C though I agree there but the fact that is has to support C leads to issues. You can access private members directly from a pointer to object - and this is directly attributable to having to support C language features. I guess we won't end up agreeing on this - it's just my opinion on writing my own bad code and reviewing other people's bad code over the years.

text: <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anders_Hejlsberg>

attachments.title: Anders Hejlsberg
attachments.text: Anders Hejlsberg (, born 2 December 1960) is a prominent Danish software engineer who co-designed several popular and commercially successful programming languages and development tools. He was the original author of Turbo Pascal and the chief architect of Delphi. He currently works for Microsoft as the lead architect of C# and core developer on TypeScript.

text: I have used a variety of languages since I started dabbling with Pascal in 1981, through University (I remember Lisp and Prolog) and then over a 30-year software development career (most of it using OO languages). But these days I am more than happy with C# as I think it is a more elegant version of C++, with some of the best bits of Delphi, and I have got used to garbage collection :wink:

text:
```>>> competition_filter = betfairlightweight.filters.market_filter(event_type_ids=[1], market_start_time={'to': datetime_in_a_week})
>>> competition_filter
{'eventTypeIds': [1], 'marketStartTime': {'to': '2020-08-28T16:31:02Z'}}
>>> competitions = trading.betting.list_competitions(filter=competition_filter)
>>> import pandas as pd
>>> soccer_competitions = pd.DataFrame({
...     'Competition': [competition_object.competition.name for competition_object in competitions],
...     'ID': [competition_object.competition.id for competition_object in competitions]
... })
>>> 
>>> soccer_competitions[soccer_competitions.Competition.str.contains('English Premier')]
               Competition        ID
48  English Premier League  10932509
>>> soccer_competitions
                 Competition        ID
0        Swedish Allsvenskan       129
1       Spanish Copa del Rey     12801
2                   Specials   2608550
3     Danish Women's Matches  12016693
4               Czech 3 Liga    892425
..                       ...       ...
82           French National   1081960
83    Irish Premier Division  12203971
84  Belgian First Division A     89979
85            UEFA Euro 2020  11997260
86         Icelandic 1 Deild  12010570

[87 rows x 2 columns]```
